introduction.p: When we discuss systems of linear equations, we are generally most concerned with systems which have exactly the same number of equations given as there are unknown variables. This is for good reasons. A linear system with fewer equations than unknowns is underqualified, which means that it is impossible to find a unique vector solution to the system. On the other hand, a linear system with more equations than variable is overqualified, meaning that it is unlikely to find even one vector which satisfies all of the given equations. Square matrices, which represent the happy medium between these two extremes, are the perfect place to look for linear systems with unique solutions.
